Question: How do I get to Metrotown via transit from SFU Burnaby?
Actual Answer: There are 2 possible routes you can take to reach Metrotown: 1) Take the 145 bus to Production Way University station, hop on the SkyTrain (Expo Line) heading towards Waterfront Station, and ride the SkyTrain and get off at Metrotown Station, 2) or you can directly take the 144 bus to Metrotown station which includes about 45 stops (~1 hour).
Generated Answer: To get to Metrotown from SFU Burnaby, take bus route 144 from the nearby bus loop. The journey takes approximately 20 minutes. Check the TransLink website or mobile app for the most up-to-date information.

How do I get to Simon Fraser University (SFU) by bus? To get to Simon Fraser University (SFU), you can take bus routes 145 (leaving from Production Way University Station), R5 (leaving from Burrard Station), 143 (leaving from Burquitlam Station), 144 (leaving from Metrotown Station). Always check the TransLink website or mobile app for the most up-to-date information.

Question: How much does the transit adult monthly pass cost?
Actual Answer: The costs for adult monthly passes are based on zones. For 1-Zone, the fare is $107.30, for 2-Zone, the fare is $143.50, and for 3-Zone, the fare is $193.80. However, if you are a student at a recognized institution in BC, you get a discounted U-Pass.
Generated Answer: In Metro Vancouver, the monthly adult Compass Pass costs approximately $105.50. This provides unlimited travel on buses, SkyTrains, the WestCoast Express, and the SeaBus. Outside Metro Vancouver, monthly passes may cost less. Check with your local transit authority for details.

How much does a bus fare cost in Vancouver? Vancouver uses a zone-based fare system. A single adult fare is approximately $3.10-$4.45 depending on zones and time of day. As an international student, you'll likely have access to the U-Pass BC program for unlimited travel. Customers can save costs by purchasing a Compass Card and loading either passes or stored value. For convenience, you can also tap your contactless debit or credit card or buy a bus transfer ticket using cash at faregates and Compass readers. Not paying your fare, or using incorrect fare, could result in a $173 fine.

Question: Do I need a Social Insurance Number (SIN) to work in Canada?
Actual Answer: Yes, you need a Social Insurance Number (SIN) to work in Canada. It is required for tax purposes and to access government services. You can apply for a SIN through Service Canada either online or in-person.
Generated Answer: Yes, you need a Social Insurance Number (SIN) to work in Canada. It's also required to access government programs and benefits. Protect your SIN as it contains personal information.

Can I work in any type of job if I am eligible to work off campus? ("https://ircc.canada.ca/english/helpcentre/answer.asp?qnum=502&top=15") Yes. Question: How do taxes work for international students in Canada?
Actual Answer: International students in Canada are required to pay taxes on any income earned while studying. If you work, your employer will deduct income tax from your paycheck, and you may be eligible for a tax refund when filing a tax return. You need a Social Insurance Number (SIN) to work and file taxes, and you must file a tax return if you earn income over a certain threshold, even if you are only working part-time.
Generated Answer: As an international student in Canada, you'll need to pay income tax on the money you earn. The Canada Revenue Agency collects this tax. If you have a salary, taxes are taken off automatically. If you're self-employed, you'll pay in a single or several payments. Each year, you must submit an Income Tax and Benefit Return to report your income, deductions, and tax credits. You may be eligible for government benefits, so it's important to file a tax return even if you have no income. For more information, refer to the Government of Canada and Government of BC websites.

Question: Can I switch majors as an international student?
Actual Answer: Yes, as an international student at SFU, you can switch majors after you are admitted, but you'll need to go through an internal transfer process. It's best to consult with an academic advisor to understand the steps and ensure it aligns with your study permit. Be mindful that switching programs may require applying for a new study permit, depending on the change.
Generated Answer: Yes, you can switch majors as an international student. However, you may need to meet certain requirements, such as completing specific prerequisites or obtaining approval from your academic advisor. It's best to consult with an International Student Advisor or your academic advisor to understand the specific steps you need to take.

Question: What does academic probation mean and how do I get off it?
Actual Answer: Academic probation means you're not meeting the required academic standards, typically a GPA below the threshold set by your university. To get off probation, you need to improve your grades and meet the minimum GPA requirements by the next evaluation period, often with guidance from academic advisors.
Generated Answer: Academic probation is a status assigned to students who have not met the academic requirements of their institution. To get off academic probation, you typically need to meet certain academic improvement requirements, such as achieving a certain GPA or passing a certain number of credits. The specific requirements can vary, so it's best to consult with your academic advisor or institution's academic policies for details.

There’s a strike at my designated learning institution, and I can’t start or continue my studies. What does that mean for my status as a study permit holder?("https://ircc.canada.ca/english/helpcentre/answer.asp?qnum=1367&top=15") This situation is beyond your control, and your status as a study permit holder should not be affected. As a result of the strike, you will not face any penalty or enforcement action because you can’t pursue your studies during this time be able to work off campus("https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/study-canada/work/work-off-campus.html#who-can") for up to 24 hours per week if your study permit allows you to work (and also work full-time during regular breaks such as winter holidays and reading week) still be eligible for the Post-Graduation Work Permit Program ("https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/study-canada/work/after-graduation.html"), if applicable. You must continue to have valid status as a student in Canada to be able to return to class after the labour dispute is resolved. If you need to apply to extend your study permit during the strike, include a letter from the registrar of your designated learning institution that confirms that the strike has stopped you from attending school and pursuing your studies.
What's the policy for graduate international students taking a term off? Graduate students must maintain continuous enrollment per SFU Graduate General Regulations section 1.4.1, and need to apply for a formal leave of absence if they require a break from studies.
What is Advanced Placement (AP)? Advanced Placement is a program that allows students to take courses during high school that can earn them college credit and/or qualify students for more advanced classes when they begin college. Usually secondary students write their selected AP exams during their grade 11 or 12 school year. AP exams are usually scheduled in early May each year and registration for the exams often opens in early March. Although it is not required, students intending to take AP courses often enrol into school based Honour Programs starting from grade 9. To apply for the Honour Program, grade 8 students will have to fill out an application form and write an exam which often takes place in January. Each secondary school has their own selection of AP/Honour courses. You may consult the secondary school in your catchment area for more information. For more information: BC Ministry of Education: Advanced Placement BC Ministry of Education: Advanced Placement

Question: How do finals and midterms typically work in BC universities?
Actual Answer: In BC universities, finals and midterms are usually written exams that assess your understanding of course material. Midterms typically occur halfway through the term, while finals take place at the end. These exams can be in-person or online, depending on the course format, and they often contribute a significant portion of your final grade.
Generated Answer: Finals and midterms are standard assessments in BC universities. Midterms usually occur around the 6-week mark of a semester, while finals take place at the end of each semester. The format and weighting of these assessments may vary depending on the specific course and instructor. Some courses may have a mix of exams, assignments, and presentations for assessment. It's essential to check with your professors or academic advisors for the exact format and schedule of your exams.

Are there any special cases where students can be considered full-time with different enrollment criteria? Students can also be considered full-time if they are in a Formal Exchange Program/Field School, co-operative education placement, approved internship or practicum, enrolled in the Dual Degree partnerships between SFU and certain colleges, enrolled under the Western Deans Agreement, are Visiting International Research Students, or have approved full-time equivalency from the Centre for Accessible Learning.
How is admission calculated for applicants with 9 to 23 post-secondary units? Admission is generally based on high school courses and grades, along with post-secondary GPA using all transferable units attempted, considering only the highest grade for repeated courses.

Question: Can I have a pet in on-campus housing?
Actual Answer: ​​No, pets are not permitted in SFU's on-campus housing. This policy applies to all undergraduate and graduate residences, including the Towers, Courtyard Residence, Shell House, and Family Housing. The only exceptions are assistance animals, such as certified guide or service dogs, which are allowed as per SFU's Animal/Pet Policy (GP 33).​
Generated Answer: SFU on-campus housing allows pets that are approved service animals. For other pets, you may need to find off-campus housing. Check with the housing office for specific rules.
